lines.text: If my calculations are correct, when this baby hits 88 miles per hour... you're gonna see some serious shit.
[repeated Line]
Great Scott!
[last lines]
Hey, Doc, we better back up. We don't have enough road to get up to 88.
Roads? Where we're going, we don't need roads.
Whoa. Wait a minute, Doc. Are you trying to tell me that my mother has got the hots for me?
Precisely.
Whoa. This is heavy.
There's that word again. "Heavy." Why are things so heavy in the future? Is there a problem with the Earth's gravitational pull?
Wait a minute. Wait a minute, Doc. Ah... Are you telling me that you built a time machine... out of a DeLorean?
The way I see it, if you're gonna build a time machine into a car, why not do it with some *style?*
Calvin? Wh... Why do you keep calling me Calvin?
Well, that is your name, isn't it? Calvin Klein? It's written all over your underwear.
[in the past, Marty observes his dad's incompetence]
Jesus, George, it was a wonder I was even born.

[to Uncle Joey as a baby, playing in his playpen]
So you're my Uncle Joey. Better get used to these bars, kid.
[Dr. Emmett Brown is doubting Marty McFly's story about that he is from the future]
Then tell me, future boy, who's President of the United States in 1985?
Ronald Reagan.
Ronald Reagan? The actor?
[chuckles in disbelief]
Then who's vice president? Jerry Lewis?
[rushing out and down a hill toward his laboratory]
I suppose Jane Wyman is the First Lady!

[following Doc]
Whoa. Wait, Doc!
And Jack Benny is secretary of the treasury.

[outside the lab door]
Doc, you gotta listen to me.

[opens the door to the lab]
I've had enough practical jokes for one evening. Good night, future boy!
[closes the door leaving Marty outside]

No, wait, Doc. Doc. The-the-the bruise on your head, I know how that happened. You told me the whole story. You were standing on your toilet and you were hanging a clock, and you fell and you hit your head on the sink. And that's when you came up with the idea for the flux capacitor,
[somberly]
which is what makes time travel possible.
[Doc opens the door and looks at Marty with a stunned look on his face]

[whilst with his girlfriend]
What happens to us in the future? Do we become assholes or something?

[Marty is showing Doc Brown the flux capacitor in the DeLorean time vehicle]
It works! It works!
[grabs Marty]
I finally invent something that works!

[quietly]
You bet your ass it works.
[Marty and Doc observe George's incompetence in 1955]
Which one's your pop?

[points him out]
That's him.
[they see him getting kicked around by other school bullies]

[has a "kick me" sign on his back]
Okay. Okay, you guys. Ah-ha-ha-ha. Very funny. You guys are being real mature.
Maybe you were adopted.
[addressing the shocked expressions at the dance after playing a wild heavy metal guitar solo]
I guess you guys aren't ready for that yet. But your kids are gonna love it.

[It's Marty's last night in 1955. Doc is setting up the cable that will channel the lightning bolt into the time machine]
... Hill Valley area weather this Saturday night. Mostly clear, with some scattered clouds. Lows tonight in the upper 40s.
Are you sure about this storm?
Since when can weathermen predict the weather, let alone the future?

You know, Marty, I'm gonna be very sad to see you go. You've really made a difference in my life. You've given me something to shoot for. Just knowing that I'm going to be around to see 1985. That I'm gonna succeed in this!
[gestures at time machine]
That I'm gonna have a chance to travel through time!
[Marty looks solemn, knowing that Doc is destined to be murdered before he gets to use the time machine himself]
It's gonna be really hard waiting 30 years before I can talk to you about everything that's happened in the past few days. I'm really gonna miss you, Marty.
I'm really gonna miss *you*.
[pause]
Doc, about the future...
No! Marty! We've already agreed that having information about the future can be extremely dangerous. Even if your intentions are good, it can backfire drastically!
[Marty nods reluctantly]
Whatever you've got to tell me, I'll find out through the natural course of time.
[Lorraine's parents are talking about Marty McFly, Lorraine's future son]
He's a very strange young man.
He's an idiot. Comes from upbringing. His parents are probably idiots, too. Lorraine, you ever have a kid who acts that way, I'll disown you.
[Stella Baines is Marty's future grandmother]
You know, Marty, you look so familiar to me. Do I know your mother?

[turning to look at Lorraine, his mother in the future]
Yeah, I think maybe you do...

[on the phone, as Marty plays "Johnny B. Goode"]
Chuck! Chuck, it's Marvin. Your cousin, Marvin Berry. You know that new sound you're looking for? Well, listen to this!
[holds the receiver out]
[pacing in front of the clock tower]

[looks at his watch]
Damn! Where is that kid?
[looks at a small alarm clock in his other hand]
Damn!
[looks at a second watch on his other wrist]
Damn! Damn!
[repeated line]
This is heavy.

[heads for a door then stops]
Oh. One other thing. If you guys ever have kids, and one of them, when he's eight years old, accidentally sets fire to the living room rug... go easy on him.
Last night, Darth Vader came down from Planet Vulcan and told me that if I didn't take Lorraine out, that he'd melt my brain.
Hey, you! Get your damn hands off her!
[repeated line]
If you put your mind to it, you can accomplish anything.
Lou, give me a milk.
[dramatic pause]
Chocolate.

[Marty places headphones over his father's ears and wakes him up by playing Van Halen music at full blast. George wakes up screaming - Marty pauses the music. George looks up to see Marty, who is unrecognizable because he is wearing a radiation suit]
Who are you?

[after giving him another earful of loud rock music]
Silence, Earthling. My name is Darth Vader. I am an extraterrestrial from the planet Vulcan!
[makes Live Long and Prosper sign with his hand]

[Deleted Scene, Doc Brown uses a sound fork and hits the time machine with the sound fork and frantically steps back]
I knew, I knew it, I knew it.
Doc, do you have a 75-ohm matching transformer?
What?

[Realizing where in time he is]
Not invented yet. That's right.

[Walks over to his future self's suit case]
So, these are my personal belongings, huh?
Yeah.

[Opens up the suit case and picks up a hair dryer]
What's this thing?
It's a hair dryer.
A hair dryer? Don't they have towels in the future?

[Picks up a pair of underwear]
Oh, look at these underpants. They're all made of cotton. I though for sure we'd all be wearing disposable paper garments by 1985.

[Picks up a Playboy Magazine]
What's... this?
[Looks at the magazine]

[exclaims]
Suddenly, the future's looking a *whole* lot better.

[Reading a letter he has just written]
Dear Dr. Brown. On the night that I go back in time, you will be shot by terrorists. Please take whatever precautions are necessary to prevent this terrible disaster. Your friend, Marty.
[Writes the words "Do not open until 1985" on the envelope]

[rushes up to George]
Say! Why do you let those boys push you around like that for?
Well, they're bigger than me.

Stand tall, boy. Have some respect for yourself. Don't you know, if you let people walk over you now, they'll be walking over you for the rest of your life. Look at me. You think I'm gonna spend the rest of my life in this slop house?
Watch it, Goldie.
No, sir! I'm gonna make something of myself. I'm going to night school, and one day, I'm gonna be somebody!
That's right! He's gonna be mayor.
Yeah, I'm...
[smiles, one of his front teeth is gold]
Mayor! Now *that's* a good idea! I could run for mayor.
A colored mayor. That'll be the day.
You wait and see, Mr. Caruthers. I *will* be mayor! I'll be the most powerful man in Hill Valley, and I'm gonna clean up this town.
Good. You can start by sweeping the floor.
[hands Goldie a broom]

[stands tall with a hand over his heart]
Mayor Goldie Wilson. I like the sound of that.
[collects George's dishes]
You gonna order something, kid?
Ah, yeah. Give me- Give me a Tab.
Tab? I can't give you a tab unless you order something.
Right. Give me a Pepsi Free.
You want a Pepsi, pal, you're gonna pay for it.

[running out of the room]
1.21 gigawatts! 1.21 gigawatts. Great Scott!

[following]
What-what the hell is a gigawatt?
Marty, I'm sorry, but the only power source capable of generating 1.21 gigawatts of electricity is a bolt of lightning.

[startled]
What did you say?
A bolt of lighting. Unfortunately, you never know when or where it's ever gonna strike.
We do now.
[hands Doc the "Save the Clock Tower" flyer]
[Marty wakes up in Lorraine's bed]
Mom. That you?
There, there, now. Just relax.
[pats a damp cloth on Marty's forehead]
You've been asleep for almost nine hours now.
I had a horrible nightmare. I dreamed that I went... back in time. It was terrible.
Well, you're safe and sound now, back in good old 1955.

[opens his eyes wide]
1955?
Let me show you my plan for sending you home. Please excuse the crudity of this model. I didn't have time to build it to scale or paint it.
[reveals intricate tabletop model of the town square]

[impressed]
It's good.
This is heavy.
Weight has nothing to do with it.
[referring to the DeLorean]

[looks through a camcorder]
This is heavy-duty, Doc. This is great. Uh, does it run, like, on regular unleaded gasoline?
Unfortunately, no. It requires something with a little more kick. Plutonium.
Um, plutonium. Wait a minute. Are...
[lowers the camcorder]
Are you telling me that this sucker is NUCLEAR?
Hey, hey, hey! Keep rolling. Keep rolling there.
[Marty raises the camcorder]
No, no, no, no, no, this sucker's electrical, but I need a nuclear reaction to generate the 1.21 gigawatts of electricity I need.
Doc, you don't just walk into a store and-and buy plutonium! Did you rip that off?

Of course. From a group of Libyan nationalists. They wanted me to build them a bomb, so I took their plutonium and, in turn, gave them a shoddy bomb casing full of used pinball machine parts. Come on! Let's get you a radiation suit. We must prepare to reload.
[Marty sees the outside of the Hill Valley High School in 1955]
Whoa. They really cleaned this place up. Looks brand-new.
[Marty and Doc walk toward the building]

Now, remember. According to my theory, you interfered with your parents' first meeting. If they don't meet, they won't fall in love, they won't get married and they won't have kids. That's why your older brother's disappearing from that photograph. Your sister will follow, and unless you repair the damage, you'll be next.
Sounds pretty heavy.
Weight has nothing to do with it.

[acting cool]
Do you mind if we... park... for a while?
That's a great idea. I'd love to park.
Huh?
Marty, I'm almost 18 years old. It's not like I've never parked before.
What?
Marty, you seem so nervous. Is something wrong?

[trying to maintain composure]
No. No.
[Lorraine takes a sip from a liquor bottle]

[grabbing the bottle from Lorraine]
Lorraine! Lorraine, what are you doing?

[starting to laugh]
I swiped it from the old lady's liquor cabinet.
Yeah, well, you shouldn't drink.
Why not?
Because you... You might regret it later in life.
Marty, don't be such a square. Everybody who's anybody drinks.
[Marty takes a sip from Lorraine's bottle then spit-takes as he notices Lorraine lighting a cigarette]

[nauseatingly]
Jeez! You smoke, too?
Marty, you're beginning to sound just like my mother.

[holding Marty's video camera]
No wonder your president has to be an actor. He's gotta look good on television.

[Doc has just been shot. Marty runs over to him]
Doc! Doc!

[Marty turns Doc's body over to reveal it is apparently bullet-ridden and lifeless. Marty begins to cry]
No! No!

[Doc suddenly blinks and sits up]
You're alive.

[Doc unzips his radiation suit to reveal a bulletproof vest underneath]
Bulletproof vest? How did you know? I never got a chance to tell you.

[Doc smiles and removes a weathered piece of paper from his pocket. Marty unfolds the paper to reveal it is the warning letter he had written in 1955, taped back together]
What about all that talk about screwing up future events? The space-time continuum?
Well, I figured, what the hell?
[1955 Doc is watching a video of 1985 Doc]
What on Earth is this thing I'm wearing?
Ah, this, this is a radiation suit.
Radiation suit? Of course. 'Cause of all the fallout from the atomic wars.
[on the phone while all the clocks chime at once]
Are those my clocks I hear?
Perfect! My experiment worked! They're all exactly 25 minutes slow!
Precisely.
Damn! I'm late for school!
[hangs up, grabs his skateboard and rushes out]
[Marty enters his house and sees Biff harrassing George]
I can't believe you'd loan me your car without telling me it had a blind spot. I could've been killed!
Blind spot? Now, now, Biff, now I never noticed that the car had any blind spot before when I would drive it. Hi, Son.
What, are you blind, McFly? It's there. How else do you explain that wreck out there?
Biff, can I- Can I assume that your, uh, insurance is gonna pay for the damage?
My insurance? It's your car. Your insurance should pay for it. I wanna know who's gonna pay for this?
[shows his shirt]
I spilled beer all over it when the car smashed into me. Who's gonna pay my cleaning bill?
Since when can weathermen predict the weather, let alone the future?

[Doc has just finished the final preparations for Marty's return to 1985]
Well, I guess that's everything.

[pause]
Thanks.
Thank *you*!
[Marty emotionally embraces Doc, which surprises him]
See you in about 30 years.
I hope so.
Let's go over the plan again, so eight-thirty where are you going to be?
I'm gonna be at the dance.
And where am I gonna be?
You're going to be in the car with her...
Right, so right around nine o'clock she's going to get very angry with me.
Why would she get angry with you?

[reluctantly]
Because, George, nice girls get angry when guys take advantage of them.

[Realizing]
Ho! Hooo! You-you mean you're going to go touch her on her -
[gestures at a bra in his hand]
No, no, no listen, George it's just an act! Okay? So around nine o'clock you're walking through the parking lot, you see us... struggling in the car. You walk up, you open the door and you say
[pause]
... your line, George!
Oh! "Hey you! Get your damn hands off her!"

[on the day after the evening Marty disguises himself as an alien and makes a threatening visit to George]
Marty! Marty! Marty!
Hey, George, buddy, you weren't at school. What have you been doing all day?
I overslept. Look, I need your help. I have to ask Lorraine out but I don't know how to do it.
Alright, okay, listen, keep your pants on. She's over in the cafe.
[George heads for the cafe, Marty races after him]
What made you change your mind, George?

[loud enough for a couple walking by to hear]
Last night, Darth Vader came down from Planet Vulcan and told me that if I didn't take Lorraine, that he'd melt my brain!
Yeah, well, uh, let's keep this brain-melting stuff to ourselves, okay?
Oh, yeah! Yeah!
[Recurring line in all three movies]
Hey, McFly. I thought I told you never to come in here.

[having "originally" - before Marty went back in time and altered the past - complained about not being very popular socially]
If Paul calls, tell him I'm working late at the boutique tonight.
Linda, first of all, I'm not your answering service; second of all, somebody named Greg or Craig called you just a little while ago.
Well, which one was it, Greg or Craig?

[a little impatiently]
I don't know! I can't keep up of all of your boyfriends!
Lorraine. My density has brought me to you.
What?
Oh. What I meant to say was...
Wait a minute. Don't I know you from somewhere?
Yes. Yes. I'm George. George McFly. I'm your density. I mean, your destiny.
Since you're new here, I-I'm gonna cut you a break, today. So, why don't you make like a tree and get outta here?
I've never picked a fight in my entire life.
Look, you're not gonna be picking a fight, Dad... Dad-Dad-Daddy-O.

[kissing George McFly on the head]
See you later, Pop. Whoo! Time to change that oil.
I know what you're gonna say, Son, and you're right.
[chuckles breathlessly]
You're right. But, uh, Biff just happens to be my supervisor, and I'm afraid I'm just not very good at... confrontations.
But the car, Dad. I mean, he wrecked it. He totaled it. I needed that car tomorrow night, Dad. I mean, do you have any idea how important this was to me? Do you have any clue?
I know, and all I can say is I'm... I'm sorry.
Do you know where Riverside Drive is?
It's on the other end of town. A block past Maple. East end of town.
A block past Maple? That's, uh, that's John F. Kennedy Drive.
Who the hell is John F. Kennedy?

[throws Marty in the trunk of a car]
That's for messing up my hair!
What the hell you doing to my car?
Hey, beat it, spook. This don't concern you.

[four additional band members get out of the car]
Who you calling "spook," peckerwood?
Hey, hey, listen, guys... Look, I don't wanna mess with no reefer addicts, okay?
Get home to your mama, boy.
Biff, help!
[the band members chase the boys]
[seeing a poster for the Enchantment Under the Sea dance]
Look! There's a rhythmic ceremonial ritual coming up.
Of course! The Enchantment Under the Sea dance! They're supposed to go to this. That's where they kiss for the first time.
All right, kid. You stick to your father like glue and make sure he takes her to that dance.
Anyway, your Grandpa hit him with the car and brought him into the house. He seemed so helpless, like a little lost puppy, and my heart just went out to him.
Yeah, Mom, we know. You've told us this story a million times. You felt sorry for him, so you decided to go with him to the Fish Under the Sea dance.
No, no. It was the Enchantment Under the Sea dance.
Then how am I supposed to ever meet anybody?
Well, it'll just happen. Like the way I met your father.
That was so stupid! Grandpa hit him with the car.

[wistfully]
It was meant to be.
[first lines]

October is inventory time, so right now, Statler Toyota is making the best deals of the year on all 1985-model Toyotas. You won't find a better car at a better price with better service anywhere in Hill Valley. That's Statler Toyota in downtown Hill Valley.
[in 1955, catching George spying on a woman undressing in her bedroom]
He's a Peeping Tom!
My name is Lord Vader. I am an Extraterrestrial from the planet Vulcan.
Marty, will we ever see you again?
I guarantee it.

[being chased by terrorists]
Let's see if you bastards can do 90.
Don't worry. As long as you hit that wire with the connecting hook at precisely 88 miles per hour, the instant the lightning strikes the tower... everything will be fine.
04 p.m. next Saturday night! If... If we could somehow harness this lightning... channel it into the flux capacitor... it just might work. Next Saturday night, we're sending you back to the future!
That's Strickland. Jesus, didn't that guy ever have hair?
What are you looking at, butthead?
Hey, Biff, get a load of this guy's life preserver. Dork thinks he's gonna drown.
It's our first television set. Dad just picked it up today. Do you have a television?
Well, yeah. You know we have... two of them.
Wow! You must be rich.
Oh, honey, he's teasing you. Nobody has two television sets.
[a switch actives Dr. Brown's television and we see a news report]

The Senate is expected to vote on this today. In other news, officials at the Pacific Nuclear research facility have denied the rumor that a case of missing plutonium was, in fact, stolen from their vault two weeks ago. A Libyan terrorist group had claimed responsibility for the alleged theft. However, officials now attribute the discrepancy to a simple clerical error. The FBI, which is investigating the matter, had no comment. Twelve wooden crates filled with cocaine washed ashore near Boca Raton, Florida, yesterday.
Say hi to your mom for me.

I noticed your band is on the roster for the dance auditions after school today. Why even bother, McFly? You don't have a chance. You're too much like your old man. No McFly ever amounted to anything in the history of Hill Valley!
Yeah, well, history is gonna change.
Mr. McFly! Mr. McFly, this just arrived. Oh, hi, Marty. I think it's your new book.
Oh, honey! Your first novel.
Like I've always told you, you put your mind to it, you can accomplish *anything*.
Oh, Marty. Marty, here's your keys. You're all waxed up, ready for tonight.
Keys?
"Too loud." I can't believe it. I'm never gonna get a chance to play in front of anybody.
Marty, one rejection isn't the end of the world.
Nah, I just don't think I'm cut out for music.
But you're good, Marty. You're really good, and this audition tape of yours is great. You've gotta send it in to the record company. It's like Doc's always saying.
Yeah, I know. I know. "If you put your mind to it, you can accomplish anything."
[Marty notices two girls walk by and looks at them]

[turns Marty's head back to her]
That's good advice, Marty.

All right, okay, Jennifer. What if I send in the tape in and they don't like it? What if they say I'm no good? What if they say, "Get out of here kid. You've got no future"? I mean, I just don't think I can take that kind of rejection. Jesus, I'm starting to sound like my old man.
Come on. He's not that bad. At least he's letting you borrow the car tomorrow night.

[sees a tow truck pull up with a 4x4 Toyota on the flat bed]
Check out that 4x4. That is hot. Someday, Jennifer. Someday. Wouldn't it be great to take that truck up to the lake? Throw a couple of sleeping bags in the back. Lie out underneath the stars.

[smiling]
Stop it.
What?
Does your mom know? About tomorrow night?

No, get out of town. My mom thinks I'm going camping with the guys. Look, Jennifer, my mother would freak out if she knew I was going out with you, and I'd get the standard lecture about how she never did that kind of stuff when she was a kid. I mean, look, I think the woman was born a nun.
She's just trying to keep you respectable.

[puts his arm around her, flirting]
Well, she's not doing a very good job.

[both lean in to kiss]
Terrible.
Marty? Why are you so nervous?
Lorraine. Have you ever been in a situation where you knew you had to act a certain way, but when you got there, you didn't know if you could go through with it?
You mean like how you're supposed to act on a first date?

[stammering]
Sort of.
I think I know exactly what you mean. You know what I do in those situations?
You do? What?
I don't worry.
[kisses him hard]
[Lorraine stops and pulls back, Marty is freaking out]
This is all wrong. I don't know what it is. But when I kiss you, it's like I'm kissing... my brother. I guess that doesn't make any sense, does it?
Believe me, it makes perfect sense.
He laid out Biff in one punch. I didn't know he had it in him. He's never stood up to Biff in his life!

[looks at the picture, realizing the implications of Marty's statement]
Ever?

[Doc Brown is trying to read Marty's mind with a geodesic helmet and a suction cup]
Erm, you want me to make a donation to the Coastguard Youth Auxilliary?
Doc,
[pulls off suction cup]
I'm from the future. I came here in a Time Machine that you invented. Now I need your help to get back to the year 1985.
My God. Do you know what this means?
[Significant pause]
It means that this damn thing doesn't work at all!
[Rips the helmet off]

[Marty has crashed into a theater after getting back to 1985]
Crazy drunk driver.
I'm sure that in 1985, plutonium is available in every corner drugstore, but in 1955, it's a little hard to come by.

[watching a Honeymooners episode in 1955]
Hey, hey, I've seen this one. I've seen this one. This is a classic. This is, uh, where Ralph dresses up as a man from space.
What do you mean, you've seen this? It's brand new.
Yeah, well, I saw it on a
[realizing]
... rerun.
What's a rerun?
You'll find out.

Look, Marvin, you gotta play. See, that's where they kiss for the first time on the dance floor. And if there's no music, they can't dance. If they can't dance, they can't kiss. If they can't kiss they can't fall in love, and I'm history.
Things have certainly changed around *here*. I remember when this was all farmland as far the eye could see. Old man Peabody owned all of this. He had this crazy idea about breeding pine trees.
[thinking Marty is an alien]
It's already mutated into human form! Shoot it!

[firing shotgun at barn]
Take that, you mutated son of a bitch!
You've got to get your father and mother to interact in some sort of social...
Wh-what? You mean like a date?
Right!
What kind of date? I don't know. What do kids do in the '50s?
Well, they're your parents. You must know them. What are their common interests? What do they like to do together?
Nothing.
Okay, thank you. That's enough. Hold it now. Hold it. Hold it, fellas. I'm afraid you're just too darn loud. Next, please. Bring in the next group, please.
[deleted scene]
[after looking at his watch George rushes to the phone booth and calls the operator]
Operator! Operator, can you give me the time?
[a few students come and block him in the phone booth with a trident]
Dixon, I got to get out! Dixon, this isn't funny! What? Dixon!
[the students laugh as they walk away]

[Mr. Strickland walks by and sees George inside the phone booth]
Mr. Strickland, those no-good guys, they just locked me in.
You see. You see what happens to slackers, McFly?
[walks away]
Yes. Yes! Mr. Strickland, you've got to let me out of here!
Where are my pants?
Over there, on my hope chest.
20 a.m. and zero seconds!
Ah, Jesus Christ! Jesus Christ, Doc, you disintegrated Einstein!
Calm down, Marty. I didn't disintegrate anything. The molecular structure of both Einstein and the car are completely intact.
Then where the hell are they?
21 a.m. and zero seconds, we shall catch up with him and the time machine.
Hey, Dad! George! Hey, you on the bike!
[Biff is waxing George's car, it's a silver BMW]
Now, Biff, I want to make sure that we get two coats of wax this time, not just one.
I'm just finishing up the second coat now.
Now, Biff, don't con me.

[stammering]
I'm sorry, Mr. McFly. I-I meant I was just starting on the second coat.
Biff. What a character. Always trying to get away with something. I've had to stay on top of Biff ever since high school. Although, if it wasn't for him...
We never would have fallen in love.
That's right.

[sees that he has destroyed the huge speaker]
Whoa! Rock 'n' Roll.
Am I to understand you're still hanging around with Dr. Emmett Brown, McFly?
[clicks with his mouth, gives Jennifer a tardy slip]
Tardy slip for you, Miss Parker.
[gives Marty one, too]

And one for you, McFly; I believe that makes four in a row. Now let me give you a nickel's worth of free advice, young man. This so-called Dr. Brown is dangerous. He's a real nutcase. You hang around with him, you're gonna end up in big trouble.

[sarcastically]
Ooh, yes, sir.

[pushes Marty a little bit]
You got a real attitude problem, McFly; you're a slacker. You remind me of your father when he went here; he was a slacker, too.
Stella! Another one of these damn kids jumped in front of my car! Come on out here! Help me take him in the house!
I've never seen purple underwear before!
[after Marty caused him to crash into a manure truck]

[to his friends]
I'm gonna get that son of a bitch.
[Marty has just woken up to a new and improved 1985, and sees his brother and sister well-dressed and sitting at the dinner table, eating breakfast]
Hey. What the hell is this?
Breakfast.
I think we need a rematch.
Oh, a rematch. Why? Were you cheating?
No. Good morning
Hello.
[Marty collapses onto the floor]

[interrupting Marty & Jennifer's kiss]
Save the clock tower!
I have your car towed all the way to your house and all you got for me is lite beer?
[chuckles]
[on the phone]
You know, Doc, you left your equipment on all week.
My equipment. That reminds me, Marty. You better not hook up to the amplifier. There's a slight possibility of overload.
Yeah, I'll keep that in mind.

[introducing his band]
All right.
[microphone feedback]
We're the, uh... We're the Pinheads.
Kids, we're gonna have to eat this cake by ourselves. Your Uncle Joey didn't make parole again.
[drops the cake on the dining table. It reads "Welcome Home, Uncle Joey"]
I think it would be nice if you all dropped him a line.
Uncle "Jailbird" Joey?
He's your brother, Mom.
Yeah. I think it's a major embarrassment having an uncle in prison.
We all make mistakes in life, children.
You really think I ought to swear?
Yes, definitely. Goddamn it, George, swear.
Oh, my God. They found me. I don't know how, but they found me. Run for it, Marty!
Who? Who?
Who do you think? THE LIBYANS!
HOLY SHIT!
Okay. Time circuit's on. Flux capacitor, fluxing. Engine running. All right.
[the engine stops suddenly]
Scram, McFly. I'm cuttin' in.
You'll have to forgive the crudeness of this model. I didn't have time to paint it or build it to scale.
Look, I'm just not ready to ask Lorraine out to the dance, and not you, or anybody else on this planet is gonna make me change my mind.
And where's my reports?
Well, I haven't finished those up yet, but you know, I... I figured since they weren't due till...

Hello? Hello? Anybody home? Huh? Think, McFly. Think! I gotta have time to get them retyped. Do you realize what would happen if I hand in my reports in your handwriting? I'll get fired. You wouldn't want that to happen, would ya? Would ya?
Of course not, Biff. Now, I wouldn't want that to happen. Now, look. I'll, uh, finish those reports on up tonight, and I'll run 'em on over first thing tomorrow, all right?
Not too early. I sleep in Saturday. Oh, McFly, your shoe's untied.
[jabs his finger up to George's face]
Don't be so gullible, McFly. Got the place fixed up nice, though, McFly.
[concerning his audition tape]

What if I send in the tape and they don't like it? I mean, what if they say I'm no good? What if they say, "Get outta here, kid. You got no future"? I mean, I just don't think I can take that kind of rejection. Jesus, I'm starting to sound like my old man!
You're late! Do you have no concept of time?
Hey, come on. I had to change. Do you think I'm going back in that-that zoot suit? The old man really came through. It worked!
What?
He laid out Biff in one punch. I didn't know he had it in him. He's never stood up to Biff in his life!

[looks at the restored picture, realizing the implications of what Marty just said]
Ever?
Now, if my calculations are correct, when this baby hits 88 miles an hour, you're going to see some serious shit!
